posts.title: Logical Operators in JavaScript
posts.excerpt: This artical tells the basic use and smart practice of three logical operators in JavaScript.
posts.text: This artical tells the basic use and smart practice of three logical operators in JavaScript. DescriptionUnlike in Java or C++, logical operators here can be used with non-bool type. If a value can be converted to true, the value is so-called truthy. If a value can be converted to false, the value is so-called falsy. As logical expressions are evaluated left to right, they are tested using short-circuit evaluation: Expression Returns falsy && expr false truthy && expr expr falsy || expr expr truthy || expr true !expr false if expr can be converted to true; otherwise, true. Expressions that can be converted to false are: NaN; null; 0; undefined; empty string(""); Replace if statement with logical ORTaking advantage of the short-circuit feature, we can easily replace if statement with || and make the code shorter. The pattern is as follow: 1234567891011121314//function 1function shortCircuitEvaluation() { doSomething() || doSomethingElse();}function equivalentEvaluation() { var flag = doSomething(); if (!flag) { doSomethingElse(); }}//function 2 :equivalent with function 1function shortCircuitEvaluation() { doSomething() || doSomethingElse();} Example 1 : Replace if12345if(a > 10){ alert('Hello'); }//the code above equals to:a>10&&alert('Hello'); Example 2 : Replace if/else1234567891011121314var b = 0;if(a = 1){ b = 10;}else if(a = 2){ b = 13;}else if(a = 3){ b = 20;}else{ b = 0;}//the code above equals to:var b = (a===1&&10)||(a===2&&13)||(a===3&&20)||0;//even better:var b = {'1':10, '2':13, '3':20}[a]||0; As you can see the pattern here is : replace if( condition ){ code } with condition && code; Replaceif(condition) {code1} else {code2}withcode1 || code2. Example 3 :Determine the browser compatibility 1234567domObj.onkeydown = function(e){ if(e){ //if in firefox, use e e.…… }else{ //if in IE, use event event.…… }} While, for shorter: 1234domObj.onkeydown = function(e){ var domObjEvent = e || event; domObjEvent.……} Explaination: If you are using IE, e cannot be used as an event object. e equalsfalse while eventequals true, so event is passed todomObjEvent. If you are using firefox, event cannot be used as an event object. e equalstrue while eventequals false, so e is passed todomObjEvent. Other Smart Practice1. Get the very first ‘truthy’ value1234var a1 = null;var a2 = 24;var b = a1||a2||100;console.log(b); //24 2. Pass default value to function parameter123function f(p){ p = p||10; //if p is not passed, make it 10}
